author: @80spaul

comment:
Great interview but I wish there had been a deeper discussion about misinformation and truth. One other part of the conversation that I wish could have been related back to that was talking about chess. Sam noted that people don't like watching AIs play chess against each other -- this is not really true, some people are very into computer chess. In particular it is the group of people who look forward to chess being "solved" I think, as well as the group of people who believe the computer can teach us things about chess that we can't discover on our own -- for instance, is this classical opening good or bad? You have 2 top engines play each other, and if one side (either White or Black) consistently wins from the given position, that position is refuted.

Anyway the reason that made me think back to the part about truth and misinformation is that I would be massively interested in seeing the AI debate itself on difficult questions. There are going to be controversial topics that perhaps the AI could find utterly convincing arguments about. How amazing would that be? And other topics that have a split decision, which is also very interesting.

But for anybody to actually change their minds, they have to believe that the AI is really and truly putting forward the best arguments possible. If the AI is trained to avoid particular viewpoints, then watching the AI debate itself has no value at all.

author: @toddmarshall7573

comment:
Humans need purpose. That usually takes the form of a job. Without purpose or productivity people become lost and usually unhealthy both physically and mentally. I'm not talking about 'busy' work either, but finding a path to contribute (in your own way) to society.

As for ending poverty. Poverty is relative and being wealthy doesn't help people have a happier or more meaningful life.  No one being hungry may be a good goal, but wealth truly does not determine life quality. Often I've seen an inverse correlation. The easier your life is, the less you value your life. If things are handed to you, you do not appreciate them and take things for granted. Society is getting far too fragile and entitled. There has to be some balance or the future will not be a better place for humans to be.

comment:
Thanks Lex, you are the most amazing champion of the new coming enlightenment age !

Efficient market theory went like this : if you see a 20 $ bill on the ground, you are just hallucinating, because if it were there, someone would already have picked it…. 
That sounds familiar again now with LL transformer M, these pre-AGI AI : if you can imagine what is going to come next with them, good or bad, you can be sure it’s already there. But if you can't imagine it, well, it may not be there before the next disruption.  “Attention was all you needed" to achieve cognitive closure of learning data…  Now we are waiting for” intentionality” and serendipity ! 
In the meantime (a matter of decades or weeks ?) well, as efficient markets never suppressed time unraveling of asymmetric information, so LLMs will probably keep some blind spots, for a while at least.

author: @AnnaGrace5

comment:
On the question of consciousness: I think it is erroneous to treat it as a binary question. It is not a question of "Is this thing conscious or not?", but of "To what degree is it conscious?". GPT4 may very well have some rudimentary consciousness, like a human that is just in the middle of waking from sleep - not unconscious, but also not fully there yet.

I also fear that it may be just as dangerous to treat something which is actually a 'creature' as a tool - analogous to the legal concept that it is better to let a criminal go than to falsely imprison an innocent.

author: @trevorwhitechapel2403

comment:
One specific criticism I don't really see brought up about these systems is regarding anthropocentric bias. I think the companies working on LLMs are generally making good strides to reduce ideological biases within the models but the data still tends to be human centric. Most humans tend to glorify the significance of our species over that of other organisms.

What efforts are being done to address this more direct ant hill dilemma? Will these systems value human progress over the progress of other species on earth? Should anything be done to address this?

author: @RobotProctor

comment:
1:03:17 "Do you think GPT-4 is conscious". Why not just ask it? I actually kind of did a couple of days ago. I asked it "As a system, are you currently active?" and after it answered yes I asked it how he had come up with this answer. It said by retrieving information about its current status. I asked if that's something it can do, then - it answered per the below: 

"Yes, that's correct. As an AI language model, I have access to a variety of monitoring tools and system resources that allow me to gather information about my current state. These resources include system logs, performance metrics, and various health checks that enable me to determine if there are any issues or anomalies that could affect my performance. By analyzing this information, I can determine if I am currently active and able to respond to user input, or if there are any issues that may be impacting my performance. This information is constantly updated and monitored to ensure that I am always available to assist users with their requests."

I mean to me - that sounds a lot like self-awareness.

author: @pl3bx

comment:
excellent episode , really enjoy hearing sam's view of future and approach however so much vagueness in the responses about everything , that its kind of useless comparatively . for example instead of "giant" amount of data , how many terabytes , how many parameters? does he agree with chinchilla paper that showcased the correlation of size of data to number of parameters efficiently ?
even when discussing "whats happening inside" the model , while a lot is still unknown i think Wolfram and Lecun had much better explanations , about a learned branching tree logic structure across multiple variables , the model is learning underlying patterns of language like how parts of speech subject-verb-object is likely one of the vectors that would be helpful to utilize , there are ~175billion such rule structures for the model to implement partitioning the word space into effective distributions .   
Sam made a good point how petty / drama focused the general public is in regards to utilizing large language models , there is so much bigger fundamental technical questions about the future , then these hyper localized quibbles about presidents or talking heads , drama news has poisoned peoples brains unable to think creatively beyond the current "issues" .
in regards to alignment , Steve Omohundro has some great talks about the subject trying to identify underlying "drives" of a rational system , and makes a good case for the proliferation of multiple open AGI , as opposed to these big corps making closedsource monolithic AGI , in that in a society of diverse AGI if one went rogue the others could collectively respond .
